p: In 2014, an outbreak of a Nipah virus (or very closely related henipavirus) occurred in two villages in Mindanao in the southern Philippines. Of the 17 person who met the case definition, 11 had acute encephalitis, one meningitis, and five an influenza-like illness. Unlike the outbreak in Malaysia in 1998â€“1999 or the pan-epidemics in Bangladesh, this outbreak in Mindanao appeared to involve horses transmitting the virus to humans. Of the 17 cases, seven had been involved with horse slaughtering or horse meat consumption and five had provided care to other patients either in the hospital, during transportation to the hospital, or in the home. At least 10 horses died, including nine that had an acute neurological illness ( Ching et al., 2015).
